Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling the Reionization of the Intergalactic Medium
Award.AbstractNarration:
Reionization is the epoch during which intergalactic hydrogen was ionized, the period when the first galaxies formed and when the intergalactic gas was significantly heated, to tens of thousands of degrees Kelvin, but despite its importance, little is known definitively about this phase transition. This project aims to resolve the impact of self-shielding systems, perhaps the largest still unquantified uncertainty in current models of reionization, through a rigorous program of numerical simulations. Prior radiative transfer simulations did not have the resolution to capture self-shielding systems, and thus misestimated the total number of recombinations, biasing their predictions for the duration of reionization.

Starting with a physically motivated model that includes self-shielding regions and explores parameter space with relatively inexpensive simulations, the work will use those results to carry out the first simulations with sufficient resolution to resolve self-shielding systems. Those simulations will verify the results from the initial work, and will be a resource for statistical studies on the structure of reionization. This study will understand how the violent relaxation of gas from photoheating during reionization influences dense gas and, hence, self-shielding systems, and will generally aid the interpretation of all observations of the reionization era.

The data set of state-of-the-art reionization simulations will be made public and can be analyzed by the scientific community. Past work by this team has been used in many unaffiliated studies and the new results should also be of great utility. Similarly, the publicly available archive of visualizations will both educate the public and help to develop scientists? intuition. Supported undergraduate researchers will be drawn preferentially from under-represented groups, and the researchers intend public lectures at schools and other venues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cosmological reionization marks a critical phase when the gas in the Unvierse transitioned from ionized to neutral, as well as when this gas was heated to ten thousand degrees Kelvin from much smaller temperatures.  The research this award supported has further developed our understanding of cosmological reionization, particularly with regard to the subsequent thermal relaxation of cosmic gas, the post-reionization evolution of ionizing backgrounds, and the properties of the ionizing sources.  A significant focus was on modeling the signatures of reionization in the Lyman-alpha forest. This research is important for interpretting observations with various US funded telescopes such as redshifted 21cm arrays, the James Web Space Telescope, and upcoming extremely large optical telescopes.

This award supported investigations into whether Lyman-alpha emission from intergalactic quasar ionization fronts during reionization could be detected with current and forthcoming instruments. We found that this signal was much weaker than had been previously predicted and that detection should be difficult even for futuristic instruments.  

In addition, we modelled how the temperature of cosmological gas elements evolves after reionization. We provided a more developed explanation for how the intergalactic temperature evolves as a function of gas density.  In addition, we developed a sophisticated semi-analytic model for the thermal history of integalactic gas that we compared with the latest measurements, constraining the duration and redshifts of hydrogen and helium reionization.  We also devised a more realistic model for how the temperature of intergalactic gas suppresses galaxy formation.

In a series of three publications, we investigated the effect of cosmological reionization on the properties of the z~5.5 Lyman-alpha forest -- absorption from atomic hydrogen when the Universe was one billion years old in the spectrum of the most distant quasars.  This forest is one of the most important observables of cosmological reionization and yet there is no concensus interpretation for what this absorption indicates. Our papers thoroughly investigation the processes that may be driving the observed large spatial fluctuations in the amount of absorption.   We modeled all possible explanations for these opacity fluctuations, pointed out difficulties with some of the explanations, and discussed each explanation's (assuming it is correct) implications for cosmological reionization.  This component of the project was a collaboration between Co-PI Trac at Carneigie Mellon University and Co-PI McQuinn. 

Additionally, this grant has supported simulations of planar ionization fronts moving across and ionizing the Universe, again in collaboration with Co-PI Trac.  We have run a suite of these simulations and plan to complete this work over the next year. Our work will provide a more detailed understanding of how ovdense regions evolve after they were reionized.  This understanding is critical for modeling reionization as these regions impede the propogation of ionizing radiation. 

This award has also supported outreach by Co-PI McQuinn and his research group.  This outreach has included several public talks on material related to this grant at astronomical societies, pubs, and science museums in the Seattle area.  In addition, it has supported the supervision of two groups of freshmen from underrepresented minorities in STEM fields to conduct research projects over the fall quarter during the 2014 and 2015 academic years through the University of Washington Pre-MAP program.  The mission of the Pre-Map program is to support early involvement in research, which has been demonstrated to dramatically improve retention.  All of the students involved (three) chose to continue this research over payed summer internships with Co-PI McQuinn and were partly supported by this award.  This award also supported two additional undergraduates for payed summer research internships.  This grant supported the training of one graduate student and one postdoctoral researcher.

The research supported by this grant has resulted in multiple publications in the Astrophysical Journal and in the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society.
